lesson.name: Lesson 2.3: Solving Systems by Elimination, Part 1

page.title: 2.3.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will add equations in standard form to eliminate one of the variables. This will allow you to solve for the remaining variable. You can then use that value to determine the value of the other variable. Ultimately, you will be able to see the relationship between the graph and solution of the system of equations. 

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Solve systems of equations by adding or subtracting them to eliminate a variable.
  • Know that adding or subtracting equations in a system creates a new equation, where one of the solutions to this equation is the solution to the system.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 2.3.1: Combining Two True Equations
  • 2.3.2: Adding Equations
  • 2.3.2: Self Check 
  • 2.3.3: Adding and Subtracting Systems of Equations and Using Their Graphs
  • 2.3.3: Self Check 
  • 2.3.4: Determining the Best Method for Solving a System of Equations 

After that, youâ€™ll practice and review.

  • 2.3.5: Practice
  • 2.3.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 2.3.2: Adding Equations
page.contents:
Activity

Diego is solving this system of equations:

\( \begin{cases} \begin {align}4x + 3y &= 10\\ -4x + 5y &= 6 \end{align} \end{cases} \)

Here is his work:

\( \begin {align}4x + 3y &= 10\\ -4x + 5y &= \hspace{2mm}6 \quad+\\ \overline {\quad 0 + 8y} &\overline{ \hspace{1mm}= 16 \qquad}\\ y &= 2 \end{align} \)

\( \begin {align}4x + 3(2) &= 10\\ 4x + 6 &= 10\\ 4x &= 4\\ x &= 1 \end{align} \)


  1. Make sense of Diegoâ€™s work and discuss with a partner:
    1. What did Diego do to solve the system?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your response: 

Diego added the two equations, and the sum is an equation with only one variable, \(y\), which can be solved. He then substituted the \(y\)-value into the first equation and solved for \(x\).


    1. Is the pair of \( x \)- and \( y \)-values that Diego found actually a solution to the system? How do you know?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your response:

Yes, when the values are substituted back to the equations in the system, they make the equations true.

  1. Does Diegoâ€™s method work for solving these systems? Be prepared to explain or show your reasoning.
    1.  \( \begin {cases} \begin {align}2x + y &= 4\\ x - y &= 11 \end {align} \end {cases} \)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your response:

Yes. \(x=5\), \(y=-6\). 

Sample reasoning: Adding the two equations gives \(3x=15\), or \(x=5\). Substituting 5 for \(x\) in either one of the original equations gives \(y=-6\).


  1. \( \begin {cases} \begin{align} 8x + 11y &= 37\\ 8x + \hspace{4.5mm} y &= \hspace{2mm} 7 \end{align} \end{cases} \)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your response:

No, adding the two equations doesnâ€™t get us anywhere. The sum is \(16x+12y=44\), which doesnâ€™t make it easier to solve.

It works if the second equation is subtracted from the first instead of added to the first. The difference is \(10y=30\), or \(y=3\). If we substitute 3 for \(y\) in one of the original equations, we get \(x\;=\;\frac12\).

page.title: 2.3.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
The Elimination method of Solving Systems of Equations

The Elimination Method is based on the Addition Property of Equality. The Addition Property of Equality says that when you add the same quantity to both sides of an equation, you still have equality. We will extend the Addition Property of Equality to say that when you add equal quantities to both sides of an equation, the results are equal.

For any expressions \(a\), \(b\), \(c\), and \(d\):

if a = b and c = d then a + c = b + d . if a = b and c = d then a + c = b + d .

To solve a system of equations by elimination, we start with both equations in standard form. Then we decide which variable will be easiest to eliminate. How do we decide? We want to have the coefficients of one variable be opposites so that we can add the equations together and eliminate that variable.

Notice how that works when we add these two equations together:

{ 3 x + y = 5 2 x âˆ’ y = 0 â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” 5 x = 5 { 3 x + y = 5 2 x âˆ’ y = 0 â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” 5 x = 5

The \(y\)â€™s add to zero, and we have one equation with one variable.

Letâ€™s try another one:

{ 4p âˆ’ 2s = -26 -5p = 2s = 29

We can add the equations, so \(s\) will be eliminated when we add these two equations.

{ 4p âˆ’ 2s = âˆ’26 âˆ’5p  + 2s = 29

                                              __________________

                                                â€“p             =  3

                                                  p             = â€“3

Once we get an equation with just one variable, we solve it. Then we substitute that value into one of the original equations to solve for the remaining variable. And, as always, we check our answer to make sure it is a solution to both of the original equations.

Example

Solve the system by elimination:

{ 4 x + 8 y = 12 4x  âˆ’ 5y = 38

Step 1: Write both equations in standard form. If any coefficients are fractions, clear them.

       \( 4x + 8y = 12 \)

         \( 4x - 5y = 38 \)

Step 2: Check to see if the coefficients of one variable are opposites or equivalent.

The coefficients on the \(x\)-variables are equivalent. We can subtract the equations.

Step 3: Subtract the equations to eliminate one variable.

\(\begin{array}{rcl}4x\;+\;8y\;&=&\;12\\4x\;â€“\;5y\;&=&\;38\\&&\overline{13y\;=\;â€“26}\end{array}\)

Step 4: Solve for the remaining variable.

\(\begin{array}{rcl}13y\;&=&\;â€“26\\y\;&=&\;â€“2\end{array}\)

Step 5: Substitute the solution from Step 4 into one of the original equations. Then solve for the other variable.

\(\begin{array}{rcl}4x\;+\;8y\;&=&\;12\\4x\;+\;8{\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}â€“}{\style{color:red}2}{\style{color:red})}\;&=&\;12\\4x\;â€“\;16\;&=&\;12\\4x\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;&=&\;28\\x\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;&=&\;7\end{array}\)

Step 6: Write the solution as an ordered pair.

    \( (7, -2)\)

Step 7: Check that the ordered pair is a solution to both original equations.

        \( 4x + 8y = 12 \)               \( 4x - 5y = 38 \)

  \( 4{\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}7}{\style{color:red})} + 8{\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2}{\style{color:red})} = 12 \)       \( 4{\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}7}{\style{color:red})} - 5{\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2}{\style{color:red})} = 38 \)

        \( 28 - 16 = 12 \)               \( 28 + 10 = 38 \)

                 \( 12 = 12 {\style{color:red}âœ”}\)                   \( 38 = 38 {\style{color:red}âœ”}\)

Try It: The Elimination Method of Solving Systems of Equations

Solve the system by elimination:

\(\left\{\begin{array}{l}3\;x\;+\;y\;=\;6\\-3x\;\;-\;7y\;=1\end{array}\right.\)


Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to solve the system by elimination:

Step 1: Write both equations in standard form.

  \( 3x + y = 5 \)

\( -3x - 7y = 1 \)

Step 2: Check to see if the coefficients of one variable are opposites or equivalent.

The coefficients on the \(x\)-variables are opposites. We can add the equations.

Step 3: Add the equations resulting from Step 2 to eliminate one variable.

  \( 3x + y = 5 \)

\( -3x - 7y = 1 \)

       \( -6y = 6 \)

Step 4: Solve for the remaining variable.

        \( y = -1 \)

Step 5: Substitute the solution from Step 4 into one of the original equations. Then solve for the other variable.

    \( 3x + y = 5 \)

\( 3x + {\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}â€“}{\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red})} = 5 \)

    \( 3x - 1 = 5 \)

         \( x = 2 \)

Step 6: Write the solution as an ordered pair.

    \((2, -1)\)

Step 7: Check that the ordered pair is a solution to both original equations.

      \( 3x + y = 5 \)                     \( -3x - 7y = 1 \)

\( 3(2) + (-1) = 5 \)                 \( -3(2) - 7(-1) = 1 \)

        \( 6 - 1 = 5 \)                            \( -6 + 7 = 1 \)

              \( 5 = 5 {\style{color:red}âœ“}\)                                  \( 1 = 1 {\style{color:red} âœ“}\)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you wonâ€™t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 2.3.4: Determining the Best Method for Solving a System of Equations
page.contents:
Cool-Down Activity

Here is a system of linear equations: \( \begin{cases} \begin {align} 2x + \frac12y &=7\\6x - \frac12y&=5 \end{align} \end{cases} \)


  1. Which would be a more helpful method for solving the system: adding the two equations or subtracting one from the other? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer to the sample response:

Adding the equations. Sample explanation: \( \frac12y + (-\frac12y) =0 \), so adding the equations would eliminate the \( y \)-variable and enable solving for \( x \).


  1. Solve the system without graphing. Show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer to the sample response:

\( x = \frac32 \) (or equivalent) and \( y = 8 \). Sample reasoning:

\( \begin {align}2x + \frac12y &= 7\\ 6x - \frac12y &= 5 \quad+\\ \overline {8x +\hspace{2.5mm}0\hspace{1mm}} &\overline{ \hspace{1mm}= 12 \qquad}\\8x &= 12\\x &=\frac32 \end{align} \)



Video: Determining the Best Method for Solving a System of Equations

Watch the following video to learn more about finding the best method to solve a system of equations.

Adding Systems of Equations and Using Their Graphs

Look at the system of equations shown here:

\(\begin{array}{rcl}&&\left\{\begin{array}{l}â€“3x\;+\;4y\;=\;7\\3x\;+\;2y\;=\;17\end{array}\right.\end{array}\)

Letâ€™s graph each equation on the coordinate plane. Identify the point of intersection.



The lines intersect at \((3, 4)\).

Add the two equations together. Simplify the resulting equation.

\(\begin{array}{c}â€“3x\;+\;4y\;=\;7\\\frac{\;3x\;+\;2y\;=\;17}{6y\;=\;24}\\y\;=\;4\\\end{array}\)

Graph the resulting equation on the same coordinate plane. 



All three lines intersect at \((3, 4)\). 

You verified that by adding the two equations in the system, you created a third equation that is also true.

The solution to the system is \(x = 3\), \(y = 4\).

page.title: 2.3.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Solve systems of equations by adding or subtracting them to eliminate a variable.
  • Demonstrate that adding or subtracting equations in a system creates a new equation, where one of the solutions to this equation is the solution to the system.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 2.3.1: Combining Two True Equations
    • In this activity, you analyzed a model representing the process of combining two different equations. You learned that when two equations that are true are combined, the resulting equation is also true.
  • 2.3.2: Adding Equations
    • In this activity, you learned how to add two equations together into a third equation. By using elimination, you created a third equation containing only one variable. This third equation can be solved to find the value of one of the variables. Using this value, you can find the value of the remaining unknown variable. You used solutions to the first two equations to test that they were still true for the third equation.
  • 2.3.2: Self Check 
  • 2.3.3: Adding and Subtracting Systems of Equations and Using Their Graphs
    • In this activity, you added two equations to form a third equation. You then graphed the original system of equations alongside the new third equation. By determining that all three equations intersect at the same point, you verified that the solution to the first two equations is the same as the solution to the third equation.
  • 2.3.3: Self Check 
  • 2.3.4: Determining the Best Method for Solving a System of Equations
    • In this activity, you analyzed systems of equations and evaluated whether adding or subtracting them would allow you to solve the system. By using coefficients of variables with similar absolute values, the equations can be added or subtracted to eliminate that variable in the third equation.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 2.3.5: Practice
